In the third part on cognition, the fourth section on cognition in the chapter on cultivation, part two. If one cultivates the cognition of suffering, does one also cultivate the cognition of accumulation?
Answer:
One should make four statements.
There is cultivation of the cognition of suffering but not the cognition of accumulation.
This refers to
when entering the realization of the cognition of the truth of suffering and the subsequent cognition of the truth of suffering.
When the arhat who has attained the state of having nothing more to learn and has already attained the cognition of suffering has it manifest.
There is cultivation of the cognition of accumulation but not the cognition of suffering.
This refers to
when entering the realization of the cognition of the truth of accumulation and the subsequent cognition of the truth of accumulation.
When the arhat who has attained the state of having nothing more to learn and has already attained the cognition of accumulation has it manifest.
There is cultivation of both.
This refers to
when entering the realization of the subsequent cognition of the truth of the path.
When the arhat who has attained the state of having nothing more to learn and has not yet attained the untainted cognition has it manifest.
When one who has not yet attained the mundane cognition has it manifest and is able to cultivate both.
There is cultivation of neither.
Namely:
When entering the realization of the cessation of dharmas and classes of dharmas, and the realization of the path of dharmas.
When the arhat who has seen the traces of learning has already attained the present unobstructed cognition, but not the cognition of suffering or accumulation.
When the present worldly cognition has already been attained.
When the present worldly cognition that has not yet been attained is not being cultivated together.
All ordinary beings, defiled mind, indeterminate mind, attainment of non-perception, attainment of cessation, non-perceptual beings, and the forbearance of the unobstructed.
If one cultivates the cognition of suffering, does one also cultivate the cognition of cessation?
The answer is:
One should make four statements.
There is cultivation of the cognition of suffering but not the cognition of cessation.
Namely:
When entering the realization of the dharmas and classes of dharmas of suffering.
When the arhat who has seen the traces of learning has already attained the present cognition of suffering.
There is cultivation of the cognition of cessation but not the cognition of suffering.
Namely:ğŸ”½When entering the realization of the dharmas and classes of dharmas of cessation.
When the arhat who has seen the traces of learning has already attained the present cognition of cessation.
There is mutual cultivation.
This refers to:
When entering the realization of the path and the realization of the type of knowledge of the path.
When a learner who has seen the traces and an arhat have not yet attained the present cognition of the uncontaminated,
When they have not yet attained the present cognition of the worldly, and are able to cultivate them together.
There is mutual non-cultivation.
This refers to:
When entering the realization of the truth of accumulation and the realization of the type of knowledge of the truth of accumulation, and the realization of the truth of the path.
When a learner who has seen the traces and an arhat have already attained the present cognition of the uncontaminated, but not the cognition of suffering and cessation.
When they have already attained the present cognition of the worldly.
When they have not yet attained the present cognition of the worldly, and are not cultivating them together.
All ordinary beings in defiled minds and indeterminate minds.
The attainment of non-perception and the attainment of cessation.
The heaven of non-perception.
When there is the acceptance of the uncontaminated.
If one cultivates the cognition of suffering, does one also cultivate the cognition of the path?
Answer:
One should make four statements.
There is cultivation of the cognition of suffering but not the cognition of the path.
This refers to:
When entering the realization of the truth of suffering and the realization of the type of knowledge of the truth of suffering.
When a learner who has attained the state of post-learner is manifesting the knowledge of suffering.
There are those who cultivate the knowledge of the path but not the knowledge of suffering.
This refers to:ğŸ”½When entering the realization of the knowledge of dharmas on the path.
When a learner who has attained the state of post-learner is manifesting the knowledge of the path.
There are those who cultivate both.
This refers to:
When entering the realization of the knowledge of the aggregates on the path.
When a learner who has attained the state of post-learner is manifesting a presently attained undefiled knowledge, not the knowledge of suffering or the path.
When a presently attained worldly knowledge is being manifested, and both are being cultivated.
There are those who do not cultivate both.
This refers to:
When entering the realization of the knowledge of dharmas on the aggregates and cessation.
When a learner who has attained the state of post-learner is manifesting a presently attained undefiled knowledge, not the knowledge of suffering or the path.
When a presently attained worldly knowledge is being manifested.
When a presently attained worldly knowledge is not being manifested, and neither is being cultivated.
All ordinary beings in defiled minds and indeterminate minds.
The attainments of non-perception and cessation.

If one cultivates the cognition of accumulation, does one also cultivate the cognition of cessation?
Answer:
One should make four alternatives.
There is the cultivation of the cognition of accumulation but not the cognition of cessation.
This refers toğŸ”½when entering the realization of the truth of accumulation and the cognition of the truth of accumulation and the cognition of the subsequent cognition of the truth of accumulation.
When the arhat who has attained the state of having seen the truths and is abiding in that state has already attained the cognition of accumulation and it is present.
There is the cultivation of the cognition of cessation but not the cognition of accumulation.
This refers toğŸ”½when entering the realization of the truth of cessation and the cognition of the truth of cessation and the subsequent cognition of the truth of cessation.
When the arhat who has attained the state of having seen the truths and is abiding in that state has already attained the cognition of cessation and it is present.
There is the cultivation of both.
This refers to
when entering the realization of the truth of the path and the subsequent cognition of the truth of the path.
When the arhat who has attained the state of having seen the truths and is abiding in that state has not yet attained the uncontaminated cognition and it is present.
When the uncontaminated cognition has not yet been attained and is present, and one is able to cultivate both at the same time.
There is the non-cultivation of both.
This refers to
when entering the realization of the truth of suffering and the cognition of the truth of suffering and the subsequent cognition of the truth of suffering and the cognition of the truth of the path.
A learner who has attained the stage of insight and an arhat who has already attained the uncontaminated cognition manifest, but not the cognition of accumulation and cessation.
When one has already attained the mundane cognition and it is manifest.
When one has not yet attained the mundane cognition and it is manifest, and one does not cultivate both.
All ordinary beings in defiled minds and indeterminate minds.
The attainment of non-perception and the attainment of cessation.
The heaven of non-perception.
When there is the acceptance of the uncontaminated.
If one cultivates the cognition of accumulation, does one also cultivate the cognition of the path?
Answer:
One should make four statements.
There is cultivation of the cognition of accumulation but not the cognition of the path.
This refers to:ğŸ”½When entering the realization of the cognition of the truth of accumulation and the cognition of the truth of the path.
An arhat who has attained the stage of insight and an arhat who has already attained the cognition of accumulation have it manifest.
There is cultivation of the cognition of the path but not the cognition of accumulation.
This refers to:ğŸ”½When entering the realization of the cognition of the truth of the path and the cognition of the truth of the path.
An arhat who has attained the stage of insight and an arhat who has already attained the cognition of the path have it manifest.
There is cultivation of both.
This refers to:
When entering the realization of the cognition of the truth of the path and the cognition of the truth of the path.
When a learner who has attained the state of post-learner has not yet attained the present direct realization of the uncontaminated cognition.
When one has not yet attained the present direct realization of the conventional cognition, and is able to cultivate both [the cognition of cessation and the cognition of the path] simultaneously.
There are cases where both are not cultivated.
This refers to:
When entering the present direct realization of the cognition of suffering, the cognition of the law of cessation, and the cognition of the class of cessation.

When a learner who has attained the state of post-learner has already attained the present direct realization of the uncontaminated cognition, but not the cognition of the law of accumulation or the cognition of the path.
When one has already attained the present direct realization of the conventional cognition.
When one has not yet attained the present direct realization of the conventional cognition, and is not cultivating both [the cognition of cessation and the cognition of the path] simultaneously.
All ordinary beings in defiled minds and indeterminate minds.
The attainment of non-perception and the attainment of cessation.
The heaven of non-perception.
When there is the acceptance of the uncontaminated.
If one cultivates the cognition of cessation, does one also cultivate the cognition of the path?
The answer is:
One should make a fourfold distinction.
There are cases where one cultivates the cognition of cessation but not the cognition of the path.
This refers to:ğŸ”½When entering the present direct realization of the cognition of the law of cessation and the cognition of the class of cessation.
When a learner who has attained the state of post-learner has already attained the present direct realization of the cognition of cessation.
There is cultivation of knowledge of the path but not of knowledge of cessation.
This refers to:
When entering the realization of the truth of the path and knowledge of dharmas.
When the knowledge of the path of the learner who has attained the state of one beyond training and the arhat is present.
There is cultivation of both.
This refers to:
When entering the realization of the truth of the path and knowledge of the aggregates.
When the knowledge of the learner who has attained the state of one beyond training and the arhat is present, but not the knowledge of cessation and the path.
When the worldly knowledge that has not yet been attained is present and both are cultivated.
There is no cultivation of both.
This refers to:
When entering the realization of the truths of suffering and accumulation and knowledge of dharmas and aggregates.

When the uncontaminated knowledge that has already been attained of the learner who has attained the state of one beyond training and the arhat is present, but not the knowledge of cessation and the path.
When the worldly knowledge that has already been attained is present.
When the worldly knowledge that has not yet been attained is present, but neither is cultivated.
All ordinary beings in defiled minds and indeterminate minds.
The attainments of non-perception and cessation.
The heaven of non-perception.
When there is uncontaminated patience.
As for dharma cognition up to path cognition, how many of the eight cognitions do they each take as objects?
Answer:ğŸ”½Dharma cognition takes seven cognitions as objects, excluding subsequent cognition.
Subsequent cognition takes seven cognitions as objects, excluding dharma cognition.
Cognition of others' minds and conventional cognition both take eight cognitions as objects.
Cognition of suffering and cognition of accumulation both take two cognitions as objects.
Namely:
cognition of others' minds and conventional cognition.
Cognition of cessation does not take any cognition as an object.
Path cognition takes seven cognitions as objects, excluding conventional cognition.
As for dharma cognition up to path cognition, how many conditions do they have in relation to each other?
Answer:
Dharma cognition is four conditions for dharma cognition.
It is three conditions for subsequent cognition, excluding the object condition.
It is four conditions for cognition of others' minds.ğŸ”½If it is the cause and the condition of equal flow for that [cognition of others' minds], it is not the object condition.
If it is the object condition for that [cognition of others' minds], it is not the cause or the condition of equal flow.
With conventional cognition, it is three conditions, excluding cause.
With cognition of suffering, origination, and cessation, it is three conditions, excluding object.
With cognition of the path, it is four conditions.ğŸ”½With cognition of subsequent understanding, it is four conditions.
With cognition of others' minds, it is four conditions.ğŸ”½If it is the cause and similar and immediately antecedent of that, it is not the object.
If it is the object of that, it is not the cause and similar and immediately antecedent.
With conventional cognition, it is three conditions, excluding cause.
With cognition of suffering, origination, and cessation, it is three conditions, excluding object.
With cognition of the path, it is four conditions.
With cognition of the dharma, it is three conditions, excluding object.
With cognition of others' minds, it is four conditions.ğŸ”½If it is the cause and similar and immediately antecedent of that, it is not the object.
If it is the object of that, it is not the cause and similar and immediately antecedent.
It is four conditions for conventional knowledge.
It is four conditions for the knowledge of suffering and accumulation.
If it is a cause for that, it is not an object.
If it is an object for that, it is not a cause.
It is three conditions for the knowledge of cessation, excluding the object.
It is four conditions for the knowledge of the path and the knowledge of dharmas and categories.
Conventional knowledge is four conditions for conventional knowledge.
It is three conditions for the knowledge of suffering and accumulation, excluding the cause.
It is two conditions for the knowledge of cessation and the path,
namely:
The immediately preceding and the dominant.
It is three conditions for the knowledge of dharmas and categories, excluding the cause.
It is four conditions for the knowledge of others' minds.ğŸ”½If it is a cause and immediately preceding for that, it is not an object.
If it is an object for that, it is not a cause or immediately preceding.
The knowledge of suffering is a condition in three ways, excluding the object-condition, for the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of origination, and the knowledge of cessation.
It is a condition in four ways for the knowledge of the path, the knowledge of dharmas, and the knowledge of species.
It is a condition in four ways for the knowledge of another's mind.ğŸ”½If it is a cause and an equal and immediate antecedent for that, it is not an object.
If it is an object for that, it is not a cause or an equal and immediate antecedent.
It is a condition in three ways, excluding the cause, for conventional knowledge.
The knowledge of origination is a condition in three ways, excluding the object-condition, for the knowledge of origination and the knowledge of cessation.
It is a condition in four ways for the knowledge of the path, the knowledge of dharmas, and the knowledge of species.
It is a condition in four ways for the knowledge of another's mind.ğŸ”½If it is a cause and an equal and immediate antecedent for that, it is not an object.
If it is an object for that, it is not a cause or an equal and immediate antecedent.ğŸ”½It is a condition in three ways, excluding the cause, for conventional knowledge.
It is a condition in three ways, excluding the object-condition, for the knowledge of suffering.
Extinction cognition is the three conditions for extinction cognition, excluding the object condition.
It is the four conditions for path, dharma, and subsequent cognition.
It is the four conditions for cognition of others' minds.ğŸ”½If it is the cause and similar and immediately antecedent condition for that, it is not the object condition.
If it is the object condition for that, it is not the cause or similar and immediately antecedent condition.
It is the three conditions for conventional cognition, excluding the cause.
It is the three conditions for cognition of suffering and accumulation, excluding the object condition.
Path cognition is the four conditions for path cognition, as well as dharma and subsequent cognition.
It is the four conditions for cognition of others' minds.ğŸ”½If it is the cause and similar and immediately antecedent condition for that, it is not the object condition.
If it is the object condition for that, it is not the cause or similar and immediately antecedent condition.ğŸ”½It is the three conditions for conventional cognition, excluding the cause.
It is the three conditions for cognition of suffering, accumulation, and cessation, excluding the object condition.
Are all the bonds belonging to the desire realm severed by the knowledge of dharmas?
Answer:
One should make four alternatives.
There are bonds belonging to the desire realm that are not severed by the knowledge of dharmas.
Namely,
the bonds of the desire realm - either severed by patience,
or severed by other knowledge,
or not severed.
There are bonds severed by the knowledge of dharmas that do not belong to the desire realm.
Namely,
the bonds of the form and formless realms - severed by the knowledge of dharmas.
There are bonds belonging to the desire realm that are also severed by the knowledge of dharmas.
Namely,
the bonds of the desire realm - severed by the knowledge of dharmas.
There are bonds that do not belong to the desire realm and are also not severed by the knowledge of dharmas.
Namely,
the bonds of the form and formless realms - either severed by patience,
or severed by other knowledge,
or not severed.
Are all the bonds belonging to the form and formless realms severed by the knowledge of species?
Answer:ğŸ”½All the bonds severed by the knowledge of species belong to the form and formless realms.
There are bonds belonging to the form and formless realms that are not severed by the knowledge of species.
Namely:
The fetters of the form and formless realms are either eliminated by patience,
or eliminated by other knowledges,
or not eliminated.
Are the fetters eliminated by seeing suffering also eliminated by the knowledge of suffering?
Answer:
The fetters eliminated by seeing suffering are not necessarily eliminated by the knowledge of suffering - they are either eliminated by patience,
or eliminated by other knowledges,
or not eliminated.
If the fetters are eliminated by the knowledge of suffering, are those fetters eliminated by seeing suffering?
Answer:
The fetters eliminated by the knowledge of suffering are not necessarily eliminated by seeing suffering - they are eliminated by seeing and cultivation.
Are the fetters eliminated by seeing the origin, cessation, and path also eliminated by the knowledge of the origin, cessation, and path?
Answer:
The fetters eliminated by seeing the origin, cessation, and path are not necessarily eliminated by the knowledge of the origin, cessation, and path - they are either eliminated by patience,
or eliminated by other knowledges,
or not eliminated.
If a fetter is abandoned by the cognition of the origin, cessation, or path, is that fetter abandoned by seeing the origin, cessation, or path?
Answer:
The fetters abandoned by the cognition of the origin, cessation, or path are not abandoned by seeing the origin, cessation, or path, but by cultivation.
If a fetter is abandoned by the cognition of the dharma, is the cessation of that fetter realized by the cognition of the dharma?
Answer:
The fetters abandoned by the cognition of the dharma are the cessation of those fetters realized by the cognition of the dharma.
There are fetters whose cessation is realized by the cognition of the dharma, but which are not abandoned by the cognition of the dharma.
Namely:
Either abandoned by patience,
or abandoned by other cognitions.
The cessation of those fetters is realized by the cognition of the dharma.
If a fetter is abandoned by the cognition of the species, is the cessation of that fetter realized by the cognition of the species?
Answer:ğŸ”½The fetters abandoned by the cognition of the species
are the cessation of those fetters realized by the cognition of the species.
There are fetters whose cessation is realized by the cognition of the species,
but which are not abandoned by the cognition of the species.
Namely:
Either abandoned by patience,
or abandoned by other cognitions.
The cessation of those fetters is realized by the class of subsequent knowledge.
Are all fetters whose cessation is realized by the knowledge of suffering eliminated by the knowledge of suffering?
Answer:
All fetters eliminated by the knowledge of suffering have their cessation realized by the knowledge of suffering.
There are fetters whose cessation is realized by the knowledge of suffering, but they are not eliminated by the knowledge of suffering.
Namely:
Either eliminated by patience,
or eliminated by other knowledges.
Their cessation is realized by the knowledge of suffering.
Are all fetters eliminated by the knowledge of origination, cessation, and path their cessation realized by the knowledge of origination, cessation, and path?
Answer:
All fetters eliminated by the knowledge of origination, cessation, and path have their cessation realized by the knowledge of origination, cessation, and path.
There are fetters whose cessation is realized by the knowledge of origination, cessation, and path, but they are not eliminated by the knowledge of origination, cessation, and path.
Namely:
Either eliminated by patience,
or eliminated by other knowledges.
Their cessation is realized by the knowledge of origination, cessation, and path.
From the eye faculty up to the ignorance to be eliminated by cultivation in the formless realm, how many of the ten knowledges know them?
Answer:
The eye faculty is known by seven knowledges.
Excluding the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path.
The ear, nose, tongue, body, and life faculties are also like this.
The female faculty is known by six knowledges.
Excluding the knowledge of subsequent cognition, the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path.
The male faculty is also like this.
The mind faculty is known by nine knowledges.
Excluding the knowledge of cessation.
The faculties of pleasure, joy, equanimity, faith, and so forth are also like this.
The faculty of pain is known by seven knowledges.
Excluding the knowledge of subsequent cognition, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path.
The faculty of sorrow is also like this.
The three pure faculties are known by seven knowledges.
Excluding the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of origination, and the knowledge of cessation.
The eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, form, sound, and touch faculties are known by seven knowledges.
Excluding cognition of others' minds, cognition of cessation, and cognition of the path.
The eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, form, sound, and tangible object realms, the form aggregate, and the first five elements, visible and resistant phenomena, are also like this.
The olfactory and gustatory realms are cognized by six cognitions.
Excluding cognition of similarity, cognition of others' minds, cognition of cessation, and cognition of the path.
The olfactory and gustatory realms are also like this.
The eye, ear, and body consciousness realms are cognized by eight cognitions.
Excluding cognition of cessation and cognition of the path.
The last four aggregates, the consciousness realm, contaminated phenomena, indeterminate phenomena, and phenomena abandoned by insight and cultivation are also like this.
The olfactory and gustatory consciousness realms are cognized by seven cognitions.
Excluding cognition of similarity, cognition of cessation, and cognition of the path.
Unwholesome and desire realm-bound phenomena are also like this.
The mind realm and mental consciousness realm are cognized by nine cognitions.
Excluding cognition of cessation.
The same applies to the mind-base and the last four aggregates, conditioned phenomena, past, future, and present phenomena.
The dharma realm is cognized by ten knowledges.
The same applies to the dharma-base, formless phenomena, invisible phenomena, impingeless phenomena, and wholesome phenomena.
The form aggregate is cognized by eight knowledges.
The same applies to phenomena with form, excluding knowledge of others' minds and the knowledge of cessation.
Contaminated phenomena are cognized by eight knowledges.
Excluding the knowledge of suffering and the knowledge of accumulation.
The same applies to phenomena without cutting off.
Unconditioned phenomena are cognized by six knowledges.
Excluding the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of accumulation, and the knowledge of the path.
Phenomena bound to the form realm are cognized by seven knowledges.
Excluding the knowledge of the dharma, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path.
Phenomena bound to the formless realm are cognized by six knowledges.
Excluding the knowledge of the dharma, the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path.
Learned and unlearned phenomena are cognized by seven knowledges.
Excluding the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of accumulation, and the knowledge of cessation.
dharmas that are neither training nor not training are known by nine knowledges.
Excluding the knowledge of path.
The truths of suffering and accumulation are known by eight knowledges.
Excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of path.
The three worldly knowledges and the three concentrations are also like this.
The truth of cessation is known by six knowledges.
Excluding the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of accumulation, and the knowledge of path.
The truth of the path is known by seven knowledges.
Excluding the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of accumulation, and the knowledge of cessation.
The knowledges of suffering, accumulation, cessation, and path, and the three concentrations are also like this.
The four meditations are known by nine knowledges.
Excluding the knowledge of cessation.
The knowledge of others' minds is also like this.
The four immeasurables are known by seven knowledges.
Excluding the knowledge of dharmas, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of path.
The first three liberations, the eight spheres of mastery, and the first eight universal bases are also like this.
The lower three formless [absorptions] are known by seven knowledges.
Excluding the knowledge of dharmas, the knowledge of others' minds, and the knowledge of cessation.
The fourth, fifth, and sixth liberations are also like this.
The fourth formless attainment is known by six knowledges.
Excluding the knowledge of the teaching, the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path.
The seventh and eighth liberations, and the last two bases of mastery are also like this.
The knowledge of the teaching is known by six knowledges.
Excluding the knowledge of the aggregates, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of the cause, and the knowledge of cessation.
The knowledge of the aggregates is known by six knowledges.
Excluding the knowledge of the teaching, the knowledge of suffering, the knowledge of the cause, and the knowledge of cessation.
The three fetters are known by eight knowledges.
Excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path.

The flood and yoke of ignorance, the grasping of views and precepts and practices, the last two bonds, the fetters of craving and pride, the last three lower fetters, the five views, the feeling aggregates born of eye, ear, body, and mind contact, the last four latent tendencies, and the fetters of craving, pride, ignorance, grasping of views, and doubt are also like this.
The three roots of unwholesomeness are known by seven knowledges.
Excluding the cognition of the class, cessation, and path.
The flood, yoke, grasping, and the first two fetters, the five hindrances, the bonds of anger, jealousy, and stinginess, and the first two lower fetters,
The body-consciousness born of nose and tongue contact, the latent tendencies of desire, anger, and stinginess, and the bonds of anger, jealousy, and stinginess, are also the same.
The flood of existence is known by seven cognitions.
Excluding the cognition of the dharma, cessation, and path.
The flood and yoke of existence, the grasping of self-theory, excluding the craving for the formless realm, the remaining four upper fetters, and the latent tendency of craving, are also the same.
Craving for the formless realm is known by six cognitions.
Excluding the cognition of the dharma, others' minds, cessation, and path.
The thirty-six latent tendencies of the desire realm are known by seven cognitions.
Excluding the cognition of the class, cessation, and path.
The thirty-one latent tendencies of the form realm are known by seven cognitions.
Excluding the cognition of the dharma, cessation, and path.
The thirty-one latent afflictions of the formless realm are known by six knowledges.
Excluding the knowledge of dharmas, the knowledge of others' minds, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of the path.
As it is said:

If the contemplation of impermanence is practiced, cultivated, and used a lot, it can eliminate all desire-realm attachment, form-realm attachment, formless-realm attachment, agitation, pride, and ignorance.
Should this contemplation be said to be associated with how many knowledges?
Answer:
It should be said:
As for what can eliminate desire-realm attachment, it is associated with the knowledge of dharmas and the knowledge of suffering.
As for what can eliminate form-realm and formless-realm attachment, it is associated with the knowledge of species and the knowledge of suffering.
As for what can eliminate agitation, pride, and ignorance, it is associated with the knowledge of dharmas, the knowledge of species, and the knowledge of suffering.
Should this contemplation be said to have investigation and analysis?ğŸ”½To have no investigation but only analysis?
To have no investigation and no analysis?
Answer:
It should be said:
As for what can eliminate desire-realm attachment, it has investigation and analysis.
It can eliminate desire for form and formlessness, agitation, pride, and ignorance, which may be with initial and sustained thought,
or without initial thought but with sustained thought,
or without either initial or sustained thought.
Should this perception be said to be associated with how many faculties?
Answer:
It should be said:
That which can eliminate desire for sensual pleasures is associated with the faculty of equanimity.
That which can eliminate desire for form and formlessness, agitation, pride, and ignorance is associated with the faculties of pleasure, joy, and equanimity.
Should this perception be said to be empty,
or wishless,
or signless?
Answer:
It should be said:
It is associated with the wishless.
Should this perception be said to be conditioned by what realm?
Answer:
It should be said:ğŸ”½That which can eliminate desire for sensual pleasures is conditioned by the desire realm.ğŸ”½That which can eliminate desire for form is conditioned by the form realm.
That which can eliminate desire for the formless is conditioned by the formless realm.
Those that can eliminate agitation, pride, and ignorance are associated with the three realms.
As it is said:
The seven types of skillfulness and the three types of contemplation can quickly exhaust the defilements in this Dharma and Vinaya.
What are the seven?
They are:
Truly knowing form, the accumulation of form, the cessation of form, the practice leading to the cessation of form, the enjoyment of form, the harm of form, and the exit from form.
Truly knowing feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness - the seven are also like this.
Should this knowledge be said to be knowledge of dharmas up to knowledge of the path?
Answer:
It should be said:
Truly knowing form is the four knowledges.
They are:
Knowledge of dharmas, inferential knowledge, conventional knowledge, and the knowledge of suffering.
Truly knowing the accumulation of form is the four knowledges.
They are:
Knowledge of dharmas, inferential knowledge, conventional knowledge, and the knowledge of accumulation.
Truly knowing the cessation of form is the four knowledges.
They are:
Knowledge of dharmas, inferential knowledge, conventional knowledge, and the knowledge of cessation.
Knowing the practice that leads to the cessation of form is four knowledges.
Namely:
Knowledge of dharmas, inferential knowledge, conventional knowledge, and path knowledge.
Knowing the enjoyment of form is four knowledges.
Namely:
Knowledge of dharmas, inferential knowledge, conventional knowledge, and knowledge of the origin.
Knowing the danger in form is four knowledges.
Namely:
Knowledge of dharmas, inferential knowledge, conventional knowledge, and knowledge of suffering.
Knowing the escape from form is four knowledges.
Namely:
Knowledge of dharmas, inferential knowledge, conventional knowledge, and knowledge of cessation.
The seven [knowledges] of feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are also like this.
What is the difference between the cessation of form and the escape from form, up to the cessation of consciousness and the escape from consciousness?

How many of the eight knowledges are accomplished in the past,ğŸ”½how many in the future,

Answer:
For one in the faith-follower stage,
at the time of the receptivity to the knowledge of the dharmas of suffering:
Without the knowledge of others' minds, one has one in the past and future, and none in the present.
With the knowledge of others' minds, one has two in the past and future, and none in the present.
At the time of the knowledge of the dharmas of suffering:
Without the knowledge of others' minds, one has one in the past, three in the future, and two in the present.
With the knowledge of others' minds, one has two in the past, four in the future, and two in the present.
At the time of the receptivity to the knowledge of the aspects of the path of suffering:
Without the knowledge of others' minds, one has three in the past and future, and none in the present.
With the knowledge of others' minds, one has four in the past and future, and none in the present.
At the time of the knowledge of the aspects of the path of suffering:
Without the knowledge of others' minds, one has three in the past, four in the future, and two in the present.
If one possesses the knowledge of others' minds, one has four in the past, five in the future, and two in the present.
At the time of the forbearance of the knowledge of the dharmas of accumulation:
If one does not possess the knowledge of others' minds, one has four in the past and future, and none in the present.
If one possesses the knowledge of others' minds, one has five in the past and future, and none in the present.
At the time of the knowledge of the dharmas of accumulation:
If one does not possess the knowledge of others' minds, one has four in the past, five in the future, and two in the present.
If one possesses the knowledge of others' minds, one has five in the past, six in the future, and two in the present.
At the time of the forbearance of the knowledge of the species of accumulation:
If one does not possess the knowledge of others' minds, one has five in the past and future, and none in the present.
If one possesses the knowledge of others' minds, one has six in the past and future, and none in the present.
At the time of the knowledge of the species of accumulation:
If one does not possess the knowledge of others' minds, one has five in the past and future, and two in the present.
If one possesses the knowledge of others' minds, one has six in the past and future, and two in the present.
At the time of the forbearance of the knowledge of the dharmas of cessation:
If one does not have the knowledge of others' minds, one has five in the past and future, and none in the present.
If one has the knowledge of others' minds, one has six in the past and future, and none in the present.
When extinguishing the knowledge of dharmas:
If one does not have the knowledge of others' minds, one has five in the past, six in the future, and two in the present.
If one has the knowledge of others' minds, one has six in the past, seven in the future, and two in the present.
When enduring the knowledge of subsequent extinction:
If one does not have the knowledge of others' minds, one has six in the past and future, and none in the present.
If one has the knowledge of others' minds, one has seven in the past and future, and none in the present.
When extinguishing the knowledge of subsequent extinction:
If one does not have the knowledge of others' minds, one has six in the past and future, and two in the present.
If one has the knowledge of others' minds, one has seven in the past and future, and two in the present.
When enduring the knowledge of dharmas of the path:
If one does not have the knowledge of others' minds, one has six in the past and future, and none in the present.
If one possesses the knowledge of others' minds, one has seven in the past and future, and none in the present.
When in the state of Dharma knowledge of the path:
If one does not possess the knowledge of others' minds, one has six in the past, seven in the future, and two in the present.
If one possesses the knowledge of others' minds, one has seven in the past, eight in the future, and two in the present.
When in the state of the receptivity to the knowledge of the path:
If one does not possess the knowledge of others' minds, one has seven in the past and future, and none in the present.
If one possesses the knowledge of others' minds, one has eight in the past and future, and none in the present.
Those of the lineage of faith are also like this.

If one possesses the knowledge of others' minds, one has eight in the future, and if the past knowledge has already ceased without being lost, one has it in the past, and if it is presently occurring, one has it in the present.

All have eight in the future. If past [knowledge] has not been lost, it has [eight] in the past. If present [knowledge] is present, it has [eight] in the present.

The dharmas not included in the faculty of being able to know the unknown, and the dharma knowledge not included in the faculty of being able to know the unknown, and the other mental factors and activities associated with the mind, form, the unconditioned, and the factors not directly associated with the mind.

Are the dharmas associated with dharma knowledge also associated with the factor of enlightenment of mindfulness?
Answer:
Four sentences should be made.
There are dharmas associated with dharma knowledge that are not mindfulness.
Namely:
The factor of enlightenment of mindfulness associated with dharma knowledge.
There are dharmas associated with the factor of enlightenment of mindfulness that are not associated with dharma knowledge.
Namely:
The dharma knowledge and the dharmas associated with the factor of enlightenment of mindfulness not associated with dharma knowledge.
There are dharmas associated with both dharma knowledge and mindfulness.
Namely:
The dharmas associated with both.
There are dharmas not associated with dharma knowledge and also not associated with mindfulness.
Namely:
The factor of enlightenment of mindfulness not associated with dharma knowledge.
And the other mental factors and activities, form, the unconditioned, and the factors not directly associated with the mind.
The same applies to the factors of enlightenment of vigor, pliancy, concentration, and equanimity, and to right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration.
Are the dharmas associated with the knowledge of dharmas also associated with the factor of enlightenment of investigation of dharmas?
Answer:
The dharmas associated with the knowledge of dharmas are also associated with the factor of enlightenment of investigation of dharmas.
There are dharmas associated with the factor of enlightenment of investigation of dharmas that are not associated with the knowledge of dharmas.
Namely:
The dharmas associated with the factor of enlightenment of investigation of dharmas that are not included in the knowledge of dharmas.
